title: Data interoperability across sectors and borders - INSPIRE and beyond

author: Michael Lutz, Joint Research Centre, European Commission

segmentation: I was a bit disappointed yesterday with some of the talks because I didn't didn't hear a lot about spatial information about Maps and not very much about data exchange standards that can be used to bring together data from heterogeneous sources because that's basically what we've been working on.
But today I've heard much more.
I've seen many Maps in the presentations of the summer, quite happy about that.
Um?
Why?
Why does Europe need a spatial data infrastructure or an SDI?
When we started the work on Inspire, we looked at some of the use cases like natural disasters and other environmental phenomena.
And if you look at these and you want to do something about flooding, for example, they don't respect national borders.
Also, if you look at some of the people that are affected by by events such as flooding.
You will see that 20% of all the citizens live within in a cross border area.
So so in Europe it's really important to to have when you're talking about environmental data as well to consider across border scenarios.
It's not an easy task to build a special data.
Picture in diverse regions such as Europe.

We have a patchwork of several countries big and small with very different traditions, different languages, different cultures and therefore with different data models and with different ways to deal with data.
On the left you can you can see an example of the vertical reference of the sea level in the different countries, and you can see that they differ up to half meter.
Between the different between the different States and if you want to bridge.
If you want to build a bridge between Germany and France, you have to be sure that you're using the same reference system, otherwise you may have a problem.
So we have very different, very heterogeneous geospatial data in all the European countries.
So what does inspire trying to?
Do about this.

So Inspire is basically a legal framework consisting of a directive that was established in 2000 and adopted in 2007, and a number of daughter legislation addressing some of the more technical aspects that I will go through in a minute.
So Inspirers is establishing in these in these different regulations illegal framework for establishing a spatial data infrastructure in Europe.

The five aspects that have been addressed by Inspire is first a comprehensive data inventory, so the Member States need to go through their public authorities and do a list and making make lists of all the environmental data under the Inspire scope that is available in the different countries.

2nd, we want to facilitate data discovery, so we want to make it easier for people to actually find out what data is available in the different Member States and that is done mainly through standardized discovery services and standardized metadata.
Third, there is a number of.
Guidelines on how to share data, how to do licenses, and how to to enable sharing of services.

The fourth point is how to make it easier to access the the data across the different countries, and this is done by having standardized service interfaces that allow you to query the databases that are around in the different data providers in the Member States and last night but not least.
And that's what I will be talking about for the most of the talk today is we will facilitate data use and data interoperability by adopting common cross domain.
Data models to exchange data.
Inspire is quite broad in terms of thematic scope.
We have 34 different spatial data themes and I'm pleased to to announce it on Monday.

We look very big day because basically we the Member States adopted the Annex two and three data specifications and that basically established common data models for exchanging data in the in all the 25 themes that you can see in the boxes on the bottom and on the right inside.
So these are all the the more environmental.

It seems that that are within the Inspire scope, but you would also you have kind of a number of reference datasets that are not strictly environmental, such as addresses, transport networks, hydrography, geographical names and so on.
So it's really a large scope that we're covering with inspire.
Part of this.
Success story of and inspires is related to the fact on how all these specifications and the legal acts were developed.
It's been a huge collaborative effort.
It's not something that the Commission has cooked up in in their own backroom, but we basically from the start.

We've tried to involve a number of experts in the Member States in the different stakeholder communities that actually are the owners of the data and that have to provide the data under the under the directive.
So we've run the number of stakeholder.
Consultation the whole process has been transparent and inclusive from the start.
As I said, we are continuously supporting Member States in the implementation of inspire and promote inspire as well in international standardization such as ice or or.
Lately we've also been close more closely involved with the W3C as well.
So let's talk about data interoperability.
Why is inspire addressing this?

The starting point and say before we we haven't had inspire is that if a user wanted to access data coming from different sources in different Member States or different public authorities, they had to deal with the heterogeneous heterogeneity of data.
There's different formats?
There's different data models, and so on.
So they usually user if they want to integrate data from different sources, they have to do a lot of.
Pre processing before they can actually use the data.
Inspire is aiming to help the user.
Are to not having to do so much preprocessing by providing a harmonized access through standardized network services so they know how to.
They will know how to access the data across all the data providers in EU and they will know in what form the data will arrive at them.
So we have we have harmonized structure and harmonized formats that the data will arrive at the user.
This means some of the job of the transformation is actually put on the data provider so they have to basically now.

Provide the mappings between their existing datasets and they can stay as they are to be used in the organizations as they were before, but they have to provide transformation to these harmonized data models that we've developed and inspire.

Another important aspect is that we haven't been looking at each of these 34 different spatial data themes in separation, but we've looked at them all together, so we have to develop these data models as a big common data model that has cross linkages across all the different inspired themes.
So there are potentially there is a big chance for creating links between these.
All these different domains like transport networks.
Elevation, utility networks and so on.
Another important thing that were inspired can be very useful in the future is to provide a spatial reference for data coming from other sectors.
That's what I usually called table based or statistics data you often have in tables.
Often these are lacking some spatial information, so by putting by linking the two things together we can.
We can support spatial analysis that are relevant for a number of use cases, such as urban planning, waste management.
Environmental impact assessment.

These are all very important tasks where you need to analyze the spatial location and inspire data can serve as as a as a way to putting your other data on the map to give it to some location information.
So the key the key into ability pillars that we're defining and inspire our forward.
I want to present.
The first is the conceptual data models that we've we've defined.
So as I said, we have a common UML model repository where we are defining the object types, their properties, and the relationships of these types.
There has been some cross domain harmonization and the based on a common modeling framework, so we have a consistent very large.
Data model that covers all of these 34 different themes.
We have defined the default encoding that is, well, first of all the conceptual models that we have on the left are basically independent of an encoding.

There is 1 standard encoding however, that is gmel the geography markup language, but it would also be possible to automatically derive at their encodings, for example based on RDF, and this is actually one of the things that we will be looking at in the near future.

Another important pillar is our to harmonize vocabulary so we have code listen vocabularies that are used for properties of the datasets that have been agreed in the thematic communities and that I usually based on existing vocabularies in these communities.
One of the the big advantages of Inspire is that we will have these vocabularies in translated in all the 23 languages.
So we have about 300.
Code lists in Inspire that will be shortly become available in a registry that there are all translated in 23 languages.

And last but not least, I already mentioned the registers we are making available registers for a number of key resource is in the infrastructure, including vocabularies including coordinate reference system, units of measure and other things that they just said may refer to in order to allow consistent management and versioning of these resources.

All of these things are defined in a number of conceptual framework documents, or if you're interested in some of the details, I'll point you to the Inspire website and you will be able to find these documents that define the conceptual framework that can be used also in other domains or by other initiatives as well.
So in conclusion, through inspire in the next 2 to 7 years, alot of data will become available from the from the public authorities in the Members.

In the Europe, EU member states and they will not only become available, but they will be made interoperable according to the Inspire data models and they will cover all these 34 inspired themes that you've seen at the beginning.

In addition, Inspire provides a comprehensive framework that can be used by others to to to achieve interoperability of spatial data and, as well, the infrastructure components such as the registry can be used in other sectors as well.
And last but not least, as I mentioned before, the inspired data can serve as as being the location enabler.
Let's say for, for, for other information, if you link other information to the spatial information provided by Inspire to provide cross sector and cross border location aware analysis.
I want to finish.
A few next steps that we're looking at in a number of projects.

We have started a pilot together with the EA actually on E reporting for Environmental reporting on air quality for example, that is using inspires as the basis an will will allow the access of comperable near real time air quality information in the future.
Then we have two projects that are the run with another DG in the Commission.
That's the digit the Informatics Director general that are.

That have approach program called ISA ISA stands for Interoperability Solutions for the European public administrations and two of these ISA projects are called Arena and the EU LF in arena we're working on.
Providing a reusable inspire reference platform which is.
Yeah, coming to the end which is trying to identify gaps and help sharing reusable sharing, reusable components.
For example, the Inspire registry that will soon be available on the join our platform that we've seen earlier as well.
We also work.
We are also involved in, for example in the the Decat application Profile Working group that we've heard of before.
The other project is looking on how we can extend inspire principles and ideas to other policy domains.
An outside the environmental sector.

Let's say, how can we develop standards, guidelines to use location information as a powerful tool also for other for other policies and the the overall goal is then to to use a more consistent approach of dealing with locate location spatial information.
Across different policy areas in the in the Commission.
That's it, from my side.
I made a few pointers to needs by a website into some of the ISA projects.
If you're interested in the more conceptual one on the Inspire website you will see you will find a high level reference report.
It's more written for.
Not for technicians, but more for.
Executive level people.
So that gives you a high level overview of what we've been doing and inspire.
And if you're really interested in what's going on in inspiring the Member States, please join us at the Inspire conference that will happen in Florence in Italy from the 23rd to the 27th of June.
You're welcome.
Thank you very much.
